awd_titl_txt: Plugging the preservational pipeline: an integrated approach to tracking taphonomic histories of Cambrian skeletal fossil assemblages
awd_abstract_narration:
Not all organisms have the same likelihood of being preserved in the fossil record. There are a variety of limiting factors (biological and/or physical) operating in the environment which can filter out more vulnerable forms prone to decomposition. Typically, only the hard skeletons of animals are preserved (i.e. bones, teeth, and shells), however does this mean that the skeletal record itself is reliable? To avoid biasing our view of the history of life on our planet this project will probe the skeletal record for leaks in the 'preservational pipeline'. This project targets perhaps the most important period of geological time known as the Cambrian Period (541-488 million years ago), during which animal life as we know it evolved and diversified. This project includes a multidisciplinary group of researchers who will sample Cambrian-aged rocks and small shelly fossils from the Ikara-Flinders Ranges of South Australia to address the following questions: What proportion of the skeletal fossil record is missing? What environmental conditions were required for the preservation of these shelly animals? And how reliable are these fossil datasets in preserving particular animal groups or for subdividing geological time? To address these questions the team will use a combination of field and lab-based sedimentological, geochemical, and fossil data, as well as advanced imaging techniques (micro-CT and 3D visualization software), to reconstruct past environments and assess the impact of preservation bias on these fossilized communities. This integrated approach has the potential to fundamentally change how paleontologists analyze and track bias in the fossil record.  In addition, the project will include training for university undergraduate and graduate students with practical, technical, and soft skills relevant to fields of geology, paleontology, and 3D virtualization. Educational outputs will include online hosted media in the form of virtual fieldtrips to globally significant geological sites and trails in the Ikara-Flinders Ranges of South Australia, and their associated curricular materials. The virtual fieldtrips will be made with the assistance of a Google Trekker -a backpack mounted with a 360 degree camera- to make accessible this remote and extraordinary ancient landscape.  

Cambrian small shelly fossil (SSF) assemblages continue to shape our understanding of early metazoan evolution with respect to phylogenetic relationships, biotic innovations (i.e. biomineralization), and the rise of Phanerozoic-style ecosystems. However, to comprehend the biological fidelity of this skeletal record requires a holistic view of the processes controlling fossilization through time and space. The Cambrian successions of South Australia -host to one of the richest SSF assemblages in the world and spanning various depositional gradients- provide a unique setting in which to investigate the link between preservational mode and paleoenvironmental variations. This project will employ a deeply integrated approach combining sedimentological, geochemical, and fossil datasets in tandem with three-dimensional volume analysis and paleoecological analyses, in order to better understand sources of bias that might skew our perceptions of this early fossil record. With a comprehensive understanding of the variables controlling select preservational modes, we can better inform previous and future interpretations of the skeletal record, not just across the Cambrian, but the entire fossil record. As such, the complimentary data afforded by this research aims to 1) compare skeletal constituents represented by different preservational modes and quantify selective bias exerted by common fossil extraction procedures as well as biological factors (morphology, composition, and affinity); 2) analyze the physical and geochemical characteristics of ancient sediments from different depositional systems to reconstruct paleoenvironment, redox conditions, nutrient flux, and sources of replacive minerals; and 3) quantify and contrast faunal composition, preservational modes, and paleoenvironment to assess the reliability and application of SSFs for regional and global dating of contemporaneous rock successions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the reliability of the skeletal fossil record, recognizing that not all organisms are equally likely to be preserved due to various biological and environmental factors. The research team employed a multiproxy approach to determine the proportion of skeletal fossil record missing, identify the environmental conditions influencing hard part preservation, and assess the reliability of these fossil datasets in preserving specific animal groups and subdividing geological time. A combination of field and lab-based sedimentological, geochemical, and fossil data, along with advanced imaging techniques like micro-CT and 3D visualization software were used by the team and their partners. The research funded by this grant involved both museum specimens from the University of Wisconsin Geology Museum and Raymond M. Alf Museum of Paleontology at the Webb School (Claremont, California) as well as field-based collections from Cambrian deposits of the Ikara-Flinders Ranges, South Australia and the Harkless Formation, Nevada USA.

Throughout the duration of the grant, the research team identified several instances of leaks in the ‘preservational pipeline’ concerning skeletal faunas through geologic time. Initially focused on small shelly fossils from the Cambrian Period (approximately 523 million years ago), pandemic-related disruptions necessitated a broader geological scope. Nevertheless, the project’s core objectives and methodologies remained the same. The investigation began by unraveling the demineralization processes affecting conulariid shells (a relative of jellyfish) from a Silurian-aged (437.5–436.5 million years ago) deposit, showcasing the impact of falling pH conditions on calcium phosphate shells (Miller et al. 2021, 2022). Subsequent research delved into the Eocene (approximately 35.0–35.5 million years ago) to investigate boney skeletal remains contained within coprolites (i.e., fossil dung) and the factors influencing their preservation (Jacquet et al. 2023). Employing micro-CT techniques to virtually extract the internal constituents revealed other preservational features, such as a preponderance of hair preserved as molds. Finally, returning to older Cambrian and Ordovician age deposits, recent work combining micro-CT, thin section analysis of rock samples, and fossils remains extracted using acid digestion techniques has gleaned insights into additional parameters narrowing our perception of the fossil record (Jacobs et al. In Press; Bennet et al. In Preparation). Limitations, whether inherent to the organisms or extraction methods, underscore the potential bias in interpreting ancient communities. In coprolites, destructive disaggregation removes evidence of preserved molds, and in limestone samples, resolving skeletal elements depends on prior preservation processes and scanning parameters of the instrument. This means that the choice of extraction method, as well as the preservational and environmental factors promoting preservation, has the potential to bias the resulting interpretations of what constitutes that ancient community.

 The broader impacts component of this project aimed to develop a Virtual Field Experience (VFE) as a means to educate students of a unique geological succession in the Ikara-Flinders Ranges National Park, South Australia with the intention of making it accessible to the public. However, due again to COVID-related travel restrictions we opted to instead replicate a local field site at Rock Bridge Memorial State Park (Missouri), frequented by our introductory undergraduate cohort. The VFE employs a self-guided field environment integrated with interactive and annotated multimedia elements including 360° images, audio/video recordings, and 3D models. Formative assessments, including synchronous quizzes, summative assessments with short answer questions and even gamified challenges were employed to evaluate outcomes. Student feedback played a crucial role in assessing pedagogical value, participant receptiveness, and identifying areas for improvement (Speir et al. 2022). Unlike existing Virtual Field Trips (VFTs) and VFEs focused on geologically complex regions, the developed VFE fills a notable gap in Midwest offerings, addressing a need in the University of Missouri Geological Sciences Department and expanding virtual opportunities in the region.

This grant notably provided support to two early career professors, both of whom are women, along with seven undergraduate research assistants and four graduate students. Among the graduate students, three are first-generation scholars, two identify as women, and one identifies as non-binary. The grant facilitated the attendance and presentation of research at a national conference for all graduate students and one of the undergraduate research assistants.


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Sarah M Jacquet
